

An egress rule ==allows specific traffic to be allowed, while blocking all other traffic==. Egress rules can be used in a variety of contexts, including: 

- Internet services
    
    Egress rules can be used with access control lists (ACLs) to grant access to a system resource from specific IP addresses. 
    
- ![](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Google Cloud
    
    Egress rules can be used to grant access to Google Cloud resources based on the context of an API request. 
    
- ![](data:image/png;base64,)
    
    Kubernetes
    
    Egress refers to traffic that flows out of a cluster, from a pod to an external endpoint. 
    

- ![](https://encrypted-tbn0.gstatic.com/images?q=tbn:ANd9GcTWRnEPwak4bG5YJ4V08MUaTAgr4HJTIx4Hcbjt2zfgQPaX7AKlgGBZ-Q__yAPhAQbPZUNmyA)
    
    AWS
    
    Egress rules can be used to update the description of an outbound security group rule. 
    

Egress rules can be used to block data egress to unauthorized locations and malicious individuals. In some cases, data breaches have occurred because organizations' egress rules allowed intruders to access and intercept data.
